verses.text_hebrew: זֶ֣ה סֵ֔פֶר תּוֹלְדֹ֖ת אָדָ֑ם בְּי֗וֹם בְּרֹ֤א אֱלֹהִים֙ אָדָ֔ם בִּדְמ֥וּת אֱלֹהִ֖ים עָשָׂ֥ה אֹתֽוֹ׃
verses.text_kjv: This is the book of the generations of Adam. In the day that God created man, in the likeness of God made he him;
verses.rendering: This is the book of the generations of Adam. On the day God created man, he made him in the likeness of God.
translator_notes: 'Book of the generations' (sefer toledot, סֵפֶר תּוֹלְדוֹת) — this is the second toledot heading in Genesis (cf. 2:4). The addition of sefer ('book, written record, document') makes this the most formal genealogical introduction in Genesis. It suggests a written source or an authoritative record.
'Adam' here functions both as the proper name of the first man and as the word for 'man/humanity.' The dual meaning is deliberate — the genealogy connects the individual Adam to the human race.

'In the likeness of God' (bidmut Elohim, בִּדְמוּת אֱלֹהִים) echoes 1:26 but uses only demut ('likeness') without tselem ('image'). The concept of the divine image is reaffirmed at the beginning of this genealogy, establishing that the image of God persists through the generations despite the fall.

verses.text_hebrew: זָכָ֥ר וּנְקֵבָ֖ה בְּרָאָ֑ם וַיְבָ֣רֶךְ אֹתָ֗ם וַיִּקְרָ֤א אֶת־שְׁמָם֙ אָדָ֔ם בְּי֖וֹם הִבָּֽרְאָֽם׃
verses.text_kjv: Male and female created he them; and blessed them, and called their name Adam, in the day when they were created.
verses.rendering: Male and female he created them, and he blessed them and called their name 'mankind' on the day they were created.
translator_notes: 'Called their name Adam' (vayyiqra et-shemam Adam) — God named both the man and the woman 'Adam.' The name is applied collectively to both, reinforcing that adam is a term for humanity as a whole, not exclusively the male. The rendering uses 'mankind' here to capture the collective sense, though the Hebrew word is simply adam.
This verse summarizes 1:27–28 in compressed form, reconnecting the genealogy to the original creation account.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י אָדָ֗ם שְׁלֹשִׁ֤ים וּמְאַת֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בִּדְמוּת֖וֹ כְּצַלְמ֑וֹ וַיִּקְרָ֥א אֶת־שְׁמ֖וֹ שֵֽׁת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Adam lived an hundred and thirty years, and begat a son in his own likeness, after his image; and called his name Seth:
verses.rendering: When Adam had lived 130 years, he fathered a son in his own likeness, according to his image, and named him Seth.
translator_notes: 'In his own likeness, according to his image' (bidmuto ketsalmo, בִּדְמוּתוֹ כְּצַלְמוֹ) — the terms demut ('likeness') and tselem ('image') from 1:26 are now applied to Adam's relationship with Seth. The word order is reversed (1:26 has 'image... likeness'; here 'likeness... image'), but the pairing is deliberate: as God made Adam in God's image, so Adam fathers Seth in Adam's image. The divine image is transmitted through human generation.
This verse establishes the genealogical formula that will repeat through the chapter: age at fathering → son's name → years after → total years → death.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֣וּ יְמֵי־אָדָ֗ם אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־שֵׁ֔ת שְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵאֹ֖ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And the days of Adam after he had begotten Seth were eight hundred years: and he begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: The days of Adam after he fathered Seth were 800 years, and he fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: 'Sons and daughters' — the genealogy acknowledges the existence of other children beyond the named son, though they are not listed. This formula recurs for each patriarch and confirms that the named son is selected for the genealogical line, not as the only child.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵ֤י אָדָם֙ אֲשֶׁר־חַ֔י תְּשַׁ֤ע מֵאוֹת֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁלֹשִׁ֖ים שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Adam's life were 930 years, and he died.
translator_notes: 'And he died' (vayyamot, וַיָּמֹת) — this refrain closes each entry in the genealogy (with the notable exception of Enoch, v. 24). The repeated 'and he died' functions as a drumbeat throughout the chapter, underscoring the reality of the death sentence pronounced in 2:17 and 3:19. Despite extraordinary lifespans, death claims each generation.

The ages recorded in this genealogy are extraordinarily long by modern standards. Various explanations have been proposed: (1) literal years, reflecting a different era of human longevity; (2) symbolic or schematic numbers; (3) a different calculation system. The Masoretic, Septuagint, and Samaritan Pentateuch each preserve different numbers for many of these lifespans. The rendering follows the MT numbers without interpretive comment.

verses.text_hebrew: וַֽיְחִי־שֵׁ֕ת חָמֵ֥שׁ שָׁנִ֖ים וּמְאַ֣ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־אֱנֽוֹשׁ׃
verses.text_kjv: And Seth lived an hundred and five years, and begat Enos:
verses.rendering: When Seth had lived 105 years, he fathered Enosh.
translator_notes: The genealogy now follows Seth's line — the line through which the story of God's people will continue. Cain's line, traced in 4:17–24, is left behind.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִי־שֵׁ֗ת אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־אֱנ֔וֹשׁ שֶׁ֣בַע שָׁנִ֔ים וּשְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Seth lived after he begat Enos eight hundred and seven years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Seth lived after he fathered Enosh 807 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues: age at fathering, remaining years, other children.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵי־שֵׁ֗ת שְׁתֵּ֤ים עֶשְׂרֵה֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּתְשַׁ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Seth were 912 years, and he died.
translator_notes: The refrain 'and he died' continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֤י אֱנוֹשׁ֙ תִּשְׁעִ֣ים שָׁנָ֔ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־קֵינָֽן׃
verses.text_kjv: And Enos lived ninety years, and begat Cainan:
verses.rendering: When Enosh had lived 90 years, he fathered Kenan.
translator_notes: 'Kenan' (Qenan, קֵינָן) — the name resembles 'Cain' (Qayin), which has prompted scholarly discussion about whether this is a variant of the same name appearing in Seth's line. The rendering uses the standard English form.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י אֱנ֗וֹשׁ אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־קֵינָ֔ן חֲמֵ֤שׁ עֶשְׂרֵה֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Enos lived after he begat Cainan eight hundred and fifteen years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Enosh lived after he fathered Kenan 815 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵ֤י אֱנוֹשׁ֙ חָמֵ֤שׁ שָׁנִים֙ וּתְשַׁ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Enos were nine hundred and five years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Enosh were 905 years, and he died.
translator_notes: The refrain 'and he died' continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֤י קֵינָן֙ שִׁבְעִ֣ים שָׁנָ֔ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־מַהֲלַלְאֵֽל׃
verses.text_kjv: And Cainan lived seventy years, and begat Mahalaleel:
verses.rendering: When Kenan had lived 70 years, he fathered Mahalalel.
translator_notes: 'Mahalalel' (מַהֲלַלְאֵל) means 'praise of God' — from mahalal ('praise') and El ('God'). The name embeds a declaration of praise within the genealogy.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י קֵינָ֗ן אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־מַהֲלַלְאֵ֔ל אַרְבָּעִ֣ים שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Cainan lived after he begat Mahalaleel eight hundred and forty years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Kenan lived after he fathered Mahalalel 840 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵ֤י קֵינָן֙ עֶ֤שֶׂר שָׁנִים֙ וּתְשַׁ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Cainan were nine hundred and ten years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Kenan were 910 years, and he died.
translator_notes: The refrain 'and he died' continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י מַהֲלַלְאֵ֔ל חָמֵ֥שׁ שָׁנִ֖ים וְשִׁשִּׁ֣ים שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־יָֽרֶד׃
verses.text_kjv: And Mahalaleel lived sixty and five years, and begat Jared:
verses.rendering: When Mahalalel had lived 65 years, he fathered Jared.
translator_notes: 'Jared' (Yered, יָרֶד) may mean 'descent' — from yarad (יָרַד, 'to go down, to descend').

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י מַהֲלַלְאֵ֗ל אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־יֶ֔רֶד שְׁלֹשִׁ֣ים שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Mahalaleel lived after he begat Jared eight hundred and thirty years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Mahalalel lived after he fathered Jared 830 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵ֤י מַהֲלַלְאֵל֙ חָמֵ֤שׁ וְתִשְׁעִים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Mahalaleel were eight hundred ninety and five years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Mahalalel were 895 years, and he died.
translator_notes: The refrain 'and he died' continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַֽיְחִי־יֶ֕רֶד שְׁתַּ֧יִם וְשִׁשִּׁ֛ים שָׁנָ֖ה וּמְאַ֣ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־חֲנֽוֹךְ׃
verses.text_kjv: And Jared lived an hundred sixty and two years, and he begat Enoch:
verses.rendering: When Jared had lived 162 years, he fathered Enoch.
translator_notes: 'Enoch' (Chanokh, חֲנוֹךְ) — the same name as Cain's son in 4:17 ('dedicated'). This Enoch, in Seth's line, will be distinguished by his extraordinary fate (vv. 22–24).

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִי־יֶ֗רֶד אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־חֲנ֔וֹךְ שְׁמֹנֶ֥ה מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Jared lived after he begat Enoch eight hundred years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Jared lived after he fathered Enoch 800 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵי־יֶ֗רֶד שְׁתַּ֤יִם וְשִׁשִּׁים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּתְשַׁ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty and two years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Jared were 962 years, and he died.
translator_notes: Jared has the second-longest lifespan in this genealogy, after Methuselah (969 years, v. 27).

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י חֲנ֔וֹךְ חָמֵ֥שׁ וְשִׁשִּׁ֖ים שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־מְתוּשָֽׁלַח׃
verses.text_kjv: And Enoch lived sixty and five years, and begat Methuselah:
verses.rendering: When Enoch had lived 65 years, he fathered Methuselah.
translator_notes: 'Methuselah' (Metushelach, מְתוּשֶׁלַח) — the name's meaning is debated. Possible interpretations include 'man of the javelin' (from mat, 'man,' and shelach, 'weapon/missile') or 'his death shall bring' (from mut, 'death,' and shalach, 'to send'). If the latter, the name may be prophetic: according to the chronology, Methuselah dies in the year of the flood.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּתְהַלֵּ֨ךְ חֲנ֜וֹךְ אֶת־הָֽאֱלֹהִ֗ים אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־מְתוּשֶׁ֔לַח שְׁלֹ֥שׁ מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Enoch walked with God after he begat Methuselah three hundred years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Enoch walked with God after he fathered Methuselah 300 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: 'Walked with God' (vayyithallekh Chanokh et-ha'Elohim, וַיִּתְהַלֵּךְ חֲנוֹךְ אֶת הָאֱלֹהִים) — a unique expression in this chapter that breaks the genealogical formula. Where every other patriarch simply 'lived,' Enoch 'walked with God.' The hitpael of halakh ('to walk') is the same form used for God's walking in the garden (3:8). It implies a sustained, intimate companionship — a habitual way of life in God's presence. The same phrase is later used of Noah (6:9).
The preposition et ('with') indicates accompaniment — Enoch and God walked together, as companions. This is the most compressed and powerful character description in Genesis.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְהִ֖י כָּל־יְמֵ֣י חֲנ֑וֹךְ חָמֵ֤שׁ וְשִׁשִּׁים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁלֹ֥שׁ מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָֽה׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty and five years:
verses.rendering: All the days of Enoch were 365 years.
translator_notes: Enoch's lifespan of 365 years is by far the shortest in this chapter — yet the narrative presents it not as a truncation but as a distinction. The number 365 corresponds to the days in a solar year, which some scholars see as significant, though the text does not draw this connection explicitly.
Crucially, this verse omits the expected refrain 'and he died.' The absence is deafening in a chapter built on the drumbeat of death. What happened instead is stated in the next verse.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּתְהַלֵּ֥ךְ חֲנ֖וֹךְ אֶת־הָֽאֱלֹהִ֑ים וְאֵינֶ֕נּוּ כִּֽי־לָקַ֥ח אֹת֖וֹ אֱלֹהִֽים׃
verses.text_kjv: And Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him.
verses.rendering: Enoch walked with God, and he was not, for God took him.
translator_notes: 'He was not' (ve'einennu, וְאֵינֶנּוּ) — instead of 'and he died,' the text says 'and he was not.' The phrase means 'he was no longer' or 'he was gone' — he was no longer present in the earthly realm. This terse statement, unique in the chapter, has fascinated readers for millennia.

'God took him' (laqach oto Elohim, לָקַח אֹתוֹ אֱלֹהִים) — the verb laqach ('to take') here implies divine removal from earth. The text does not say where God took him or what form this taking assumed. Later tradition understood it as bodily translation to heaven (cf. Hebrews 11:5; Sirach 44:16; 49:14). The only other person described as being 'taken' by God is Elijah (2 Kings 2:1–11).

In a genealogy dominated by death, Enoch's entry stands as a dramatic exception. The pattern of 'and he died... and he died... and he died' is broken by a life so characterized by walking with God that death is bypassed entirely. The contrast gives the chapter a theological dimension beyond mere record-keeping.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י מְתוּשֶׁ֔לַח שֶׁ֧בַע וּשְׁמֹנִ֛ים שָׁנָ֖ה וּמְאַ֣ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־לָֽמֶךְ׃
verses.text_kjv: And Methuselah lived an hundred eighty and seven years, and begat Lamech:
verses.rendering: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he fathered Lamech.
translator_notes: 'Lamech' (לָמֶךְ) — the same name as the violent descendant of Cain (4:18–24), but a different person. The name's meaning is uncertain.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִ֣י מְתוּשֶׁ֗לַח אַֽחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־לֶ֔מֶךְ שְׁתַּ֤יִם וּשְׁמוֹנִים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁבַ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Methuselah lived after he begat Lamech seven hundred eighty and two years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Methuselah lived after he fathered Lamech 782 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern continues.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּהְי֞וּ כָּל־יְמֵ֤י מְתוּשֶׁ֙לַח֙ תֵּ֤שַׁע וְשִׁשִּׁים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּתְשַׁ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty and nine years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Methuselah were 969 years, and he died.
translator_notes: Methuselah's 969 years make him the longest-lived person recorded in the Bible. According to the MT chronology, Methuselah dies in the year of the flood (his birth year + his age at death = the year of the flood in 7:6). Whether this is coincidental or intentional is debated; if intentional, it suggests he died in the flood or immediately before it.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיְחִי־לֶ֕מֶךְ שְׁתַּ֧יִם וּשְׁמֹנִ֛ים שָׁנָ֖ה וּמְאַ֣ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד בֵּֽן׃
verses.text_kjv: And Lamech lived an hundred eighty and two years, and begat a son:
verses.rendering: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he fathered a son.
translator_notes: Lamech's entry breaks the formula by not immediately naming his son. Instead, the naming and its explanation are given in the next verse — the most theologically significant naming in the genealogy.

verses.text_hebrew: וַיִּקְרָ֧א אֶת־שְׁמ֛וֹ נֹ֖חַ לֵאמֹ֑ר זֶ֠ה יְנַחֲמֵ֤נוּ מִמַּעֲשֵׂ֙נוּ֙ וּמֵעִצְּב֣וֹן יָדֵ֔ינוּ מִן־הָ֣אֲדָמָ֔ה אֲשֶׁ֥ר אֵֽרְרָ֖הּ יְהוָֽה׃
verses.text_kjv: And he called his name Noah, saying, This same shall comfort us concerning our work and toil of our hands, because of the ground which the LORD hath cursed.
verses.rendering: He named him Noah, saying, "This one will bring us relief from our work and from the painful toil of our hands, from the ground that the LORD has cursed."
translator_notes: 'Noah' (Noach, נֹחַ) — the name is explained with a wordplay, though it is not a direct etymological match. Noach is related to nuach (נוּחַ, 'to rest'), but Lamech's explanation uses the verb nacham (נָחַם, 'to comfort, to bring relief'). The sound connection (noach/yenachamenu) creates the wordplay even though the roots differ: Noah ('rest') will 'comfort/relieve' (nacham) them. 'Relief' is used to capture the nuach/nacham overlap.

'Painful toil of our hands' (itstsevon yadenu, עִצְּבוֹן יָדֵינוּ) — the word itstsavon is the same root used for the woman's pain in childbearing (3:16) and the man's painful toil with the ground (3:17). Lamech's lament explicitly references the curse of 3:17 ('the ground that the LORD has cursed') — the consequences of the fall are still felt and still lamented generations later.
Lamech's hope that Noah will bring relief from the curse anticipates Noah's role in the flood narrative — though the 'relief' comes in a way no one expected.

key_terms.note: The name derives from nuach ('to rest') but is explained with nacham ('to comfort/relieve'). Noah represents a hope for respite from the curse — a hope that will be fulfilled through catastrophe and renewal.

verses.text_hebrew: וַֽיְחִי־לֶ֗מֶךְ אַחֲרֵי֙ הוֹלִיד֣וֹ אֶת־נֹ֔חַ חָמֵ֤שׁ וְתִשְׁעִים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וַחֲמֵ֥שׁ מֵאֹ֖ת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֥וֹלֶד בָּנִ֖ים וּבָנֽוֹת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Lamech lived after he begat Noah five hundred ninety and five years, and begat sons and daughters:
verses.rendering: Lamech lived after he fathered Noah 595 years and fathered sons and daughters.
translator_notes: The formulaic pattern resumes.

verses.text_hebrew: וַֽיְהִי֙ כָּל־יְמֵי־לֶ֔מֶךְ שֶׁ֤בַע וְשִׁבְעִים֙ שָׁנָ֔ה וּשְׁבַ֥ע מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיָּמֹֽת׃
verses.text_kjv: And all the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy and seven years: and he died.
verses.rendering: All the days of Lamech were 777 years, and he died.
translator_notes: Lamech's lifespan of 777 years contains the number seven three times. Whether this is numerically significant or coincidental is debated. In light of Lamech of Cain's line claiming 'seventy-sevenfold' vengeance (4:24), the sevens in this Lamech's lifespan may create an intentional contrast between the line of violence and the line of faith.

verses.text_hebrew: וַֽיְהִי־נֹ֕חַ בֶּן־חֲמֵ֥שׁ מֵא֖וֹת שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֣וֹלֶד נֹ֔חַ אֶת־שֵׁ֖ם אֶת־חָ֥ם וְאֶת־יָֽפֶת׃
verses.text_kjv: And Noah was five hundred years old: and Noah begat Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.rendering: After Noah was 500 years old, Noah fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
translator_notes: The genealogy ends without the formula 'and he died' for Noah — his story continues in the following chapters. Noah's entry lacks the closure that every other patriarch receives (except Enoch, for a different reason). Noah's death is not recorded until 9:29.

'Shem, Ham, and Japheth' — the three sons of Noah who will become the ancestors of all post-flood humanity (chapters 9–10). 'Shem' (שֵׁם) means 'name' or 'renown'; 'Ham' (חָם) means 'hot' or 'warm'; 'Japheth' (יָפֶת) may mean 'enlarged' or 'beautiful,' related to the root y-p-h ('beauty') or p-t-h ('to enlarge'). Though listed in this order, Shem may not be the eldest (cf. 10:21, which is ambiguous).
